original_data.question:
A 26-year-old man presents to the office complaining of persistent epigastric pain for the past 2 months. He states that his pain is worse a few hours after he eats. His father had similar symptoms. Past medical history is insignificant. He is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. The vital signs include blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg, heart rate 83/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination is insignificant except for mild epigastric tenderness. A metabolic panel reveals the following:
Serum sodium 136 mEq/L
Serum potassium 4.2 mEq/L
Calcium 13.2 mg/dL
Bicarbonate 26 mEq/L
Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals multiple duodenal ulcers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

model_response:
This patient has a typical presentation of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES). ZES is a non-beta islet cell tumor of the pancreas that secretes gastrin. The gastrin increases the acid production in the stomach, leading to the formation of multiple duodenal ulcers. The patient with ZES typically presents with epigastric pain that is worse with eating. The pain is due to the increased acid production and results in a cycle of pain, increased eating, and increased acid production. The increased acid production can also result in esophagitis and gastroesophageal reflux. The increased acid production is rarely due to a non-beta islet cell tumor of the pancreas. More commonly, the increased acid production is due to a gastrin-producing tumor of the pancreas. The gastrinoma is most commonly found in the head of the pancreas. The increased gastrin production is not due to a beta cell tumor of the pancreas. The beta cell tumor of the pancreas is most commonly associated with diabetes mellitus and hyperinsulinemia. The increased gastrin production is not due to a non-beta islet cell tumor of the pancreas. The non-beta islet cell tumor of the pancreas is most commonly associated with pheochromocytoma and hypercalcemia.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
Retained; never-ceasing.
The location of the pain is in the upper and middle region of the abdomen, located within the sternal angle.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
A constituent administrative district of a nation.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
The edible portions of any animal used for food including cattle, swine, goats/sheep, poultry, fish, shellfish, and game.
Male parents, human or animal.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

A term applied to differences, correlations, cause-and-effect relationships, etc., to indicate that they are noticeable, probably too closely correlated to be attributed to chance and therefore indicating a systematic relation: substantial, fairly large; also having consequence or import, important in effect or meaning. In statistics significant ordinarily indicates a probability of not less than 95 percent, while highly significant indicates a probability of not less than 99 percent.

A clear, colorless liquid rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and distributed throughout the body. It has bactericidal activity and is used often as a topical disinfectant. It is widely used as a solvent and preservative in pharmaceutical preparations as well as serving as the primary ingredient in ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.

A term applied to differences, correlations, cause-and-effect relationships, etc., to indicate that they are noticeable, probably too closely correlated to be attributed to chance and therefore indicating a systematic relation: substantial, fairly large; also having consequence or import, important in effect or meaning. In statistics significant ordinarily indicates a probability of not less than 95 percent, while highly significant indicates a probability of not less than 99 percent.
The chemical reactions and pathways by which individual cells transform chemical substances. [GOC:go_curators]
A quantitative measurement of the amount of sodium present in a sample of serum.
A quantitative measurement of the amount of potassium present in a sample of serum.

Inorganic salts that contain the -HCO3 radical. They are an important factor in determining the pH of the blood and the concentration of bicarbonate ions is regulated by the kidney. Levels in the blood are an index of the alkali reserve or buffering capacity.
An endoscopic procedure that visualizes the upper part of the gastrointestinal tract up to the duodenum.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
